head.title: Appeals Court Returns Case in Agent's Slaying

hedline.hl1: Appeals Court Returns Case in Agent's Slaying

block.p: The United States cannot kidnap someone from a foreign country and prosecute that person over the other country's objections, a federal appeals court ruled today in teh case of the torture slaying of a Federal drug agent.

The ruling, by the Circuit Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, in San Francisco, would require a Federal judge to reverse the murder conviction of Rene Verdugo-Urquidez if the judge decided that the kidnapping of Mr. Verdugo-Urquidez in Mexico was arranged by United States agents and that the Mexican Government objected.

The United States cannot kidnap someone from a foreign country and prosecute that person over the other country's objections, a federal appeals court ruled today in teh case of the torture slaying of a Federal drug agent.

The ruling, by the Circuit Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, in San Francisco, would require a Federal judge to reverse the murder conviction of Rene Verdugo-Urquidez if the judge decided that the kidnapping of Mr. Verdugo-Urquidez in Mexico was arranged by United States agents and that the Mexican Government objected.
Mr. Verdugo-Urquidez was sentenced to 240 years in prison. He would be returned to Mexico if his conviction was reversed.
A Justice Department spokesman, Doug Tillett, said the Government expected to appeal the ruling to a larger panel of the ocurt, and if necessary to the Supreme Court.

Mr. Verdugo-Urquidez is one of more than two dozen people who have been convicted in Mexico and the United States in the 1985 killings of Enrique Camarena Salazar, a Drug Enforcement Administration agent, and a pilot who was with him.
